answer:
**Frame‐by‐Frame Analysis**

1. **Frame 1 & Frame 2:** The camera is behind a black SUV in what appears to be a “main” through‐lane. There is another lane to the right, but no clear signage yet.  
2. **Frame 3:** Construction barriers on the right become more evident, suggesting some lane reconfiguration. Still no visible “must turn” markings.  
3. **Frame 4:** A sign on the right says “RIGHT LANE MUST TURN RIGHT.” No comparable sign for the left lane is visible, so the left (or center) lane(s) presumably can proceed straight.  
4. **Frame 5:** The “Right Lane Must Turn Right” sign is even clearer. There is no indication that the left lane(s) are forced to turn left.

**Contextual Reasoning**

Since the only posted restriction is on the right lane (“must turn right”), at least one lane to its left is free to continue straight. There is no signage forcing the left or “middle” lane to turn left. It therefore appears that two lanes—everything except the far right lane—are allowed to continue straight on through the intersection.

**Matching to the Answer Choices**

• (A) “The left two lanes” matches the signage: the right lane must turn right, so the remaining two lanes (left and center) can go straight.  
• (B) “The right two lanes” conflicts with the “Right Lane Must Turn Right” sign.  
• (C) “All the lanes” also conflicts with the “Right Lane Must Turn Right” sign.  
• (D) “The middle lane” alone is too restrictive; there is no sign preventing the left lane from going straight as well.

**Provide the Best Answer**

<answer>A</answer>
